EVENT: Compound microscope invented by Hans and Zacharias Janssen
SIGNIFICANCE: First microscope with multiple lenses. Inspires Galileo to experiment further with telescopes and microscopes.
Early colonial settlement in US.
Expands upon Hans and Zacharias Janssen's work. Galileo's creates a focusing device and describes principles of lenses and light rays.
First pharmacopeia in London, one of the earliest in existence. Officially sanctioned by King James I, apothecaries in London are only allowed to compound drugs that appear in the pharmacopeia.

EVENT: Boston is founded and Governor John Winthrop takes an avid interest in preparing medicines
SIGNIFICANCE: By necessity, Winthrop becomes the de facto colonial apothecary. Using his home as a base of operations, he imports herbs and drugs from the Old World, becoming one of the first people in North America to prepare pharmaceuticals.

EVENT: Scottish apothecary John Johnstone founds a settlement in what will later become New Jersey
SIGNIFICANCE: One of the earliest American apothecaries.

EVENT: Jeanne Mance establishes Hotel Dieu of Montreal
SIGNIFICANCE: An early Canadian hospital, the first in Montreal. Part of the "Hotel Dieu" family of hopsitals, run by nuns.

EVENT: First mention of a dispensary in British North America, operated by William Davis of Boston
SIGNIFICANCE: One of the earliest American apothecaries.

EVENT: Dutch surgeon Gysbert van Imbroch practices medicine and sells drugs in what will later become New York
SIGNIFICANCE: One of the earliest American apothecaries, possibly the first surgeon in colonial America.

EVENT: Robert Boyle publishes Certain Physiological Essays
SIGNIFICANCE: Popular work of European scholarship on physiology.
The bubonic plague ravages the city of London, killing over 100,000 people.

EVENT: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek describes and sketches bacteria
SIGNIFICANCE: First scientist to observe bacteria and protozoa.

EVENT: Elizabeth Gooking Greenleaf opens an apothecary shop with her husband in Boston.
SIGNIFICANCE: One of the earliest American apothecaries, and likely the first female apothecary in the country.

EVENT: John Bartram establishes first botanical garden in US (Philadelphia)
SIGNIFICANCE: Called the "Father of American Botany," Bartram is the first North American scientist to work in hybridization. He collects and exports seeds to Europe, creating international collaboration.

EVENT: Irish immigrant Christopher Marshall establishes an apothecary shop in Philadelphia
SIGNIFICANCE: Marshall manufactures drugs, sells them wholesale to physicians, and trains apprentice apothecaries. During the American Revolution, he supplies medicines to the American troops under General George Washington.

EVENT: Apothecary Andreas Marggraf discovers magnesia and alum
Dr. Thomas Bond and Benjamin Franklin establish Pennsylvania Hospital
SIGNIFICANCE: The first hospital in America. Plays a major role in the Revolutionary War, tending to both Continental and British soldiers. Official seal bears the words “Take care of him and I will repay thee,” a reference to the biblical story of the Good Samaritan. The Pennsylvania Hospital remains in operation to this day.

EVENT: Jonathan Roberts becomes America’s first hospital pharmacist
SIGNIFICANCE: Like many early apothecaries, Roberts begins as an apprentice physician. He works at the newly-established Pennsylvania Hospital.

EVENT: Benedict Arnold owns and operates a drugstore in New Haven, CT
SIGNIFICANCE: Prior to the Revolutionary War, Arnold owns a store that sells books and drugs. The shop is financed in large part through an inheritance from Arnold's father, who died in 1761.
Cavendish originally refers to hydrogren as "inflammable air."

EVENT: First medical degree conferred in America
SIGNIFICANCE: Robert Tucker receives the country's first M.D. degree from King's College (now Columbia University).

EVENT: Apothecary Carl Wilhelm Scheele discovers oxygen
SIGNIFICANCE: Scheele publishes his discovery in Chemische Abhandlung von der Luft und dem Feuer (Chemical Treatise on Air and Fire) in 1777. He later discovers chlorine, manganese, arsenite of copper, molybdenum, uric acid, lactic acid, gallic acid, malic acid, hydrocyanic acid, and glycerin.

EVENT: Joseph Priestley discovers nitrogen and oxygen
SIGNIFICANCE: Priestley's discovery is independent of Scheele's, but happens at almost the same time.

EVENT: Andrew Craigie becomes first US Army apothecary
SIGNIFICANCE: Following the establishment of the Continental Army, Craigie is selected “to take care of the medical stores, and to deliver them out as ordered by [the Massachusetts Congress]." He is present at the Battle of Bunker Hill, where he treats the war-wounded.

EVENT: Lavoisier described exchange of gases in respiration
SIGNIFICANCE: First observation of the exchange of gases in breathing.

EVENT: First use of cod liver oil by English physicians
SIGNIFICANCE: Earliest use of a compound that will go on to be used for centuries.

EVENT: Martin Kalproth discovers uranium and zirconium
SIGNIFICANCE: He later goes on to discover cerium in 1803.

EVENT: Benjamin Bell differentiates gonorrhea from syphilis
SIGNIFICANCE: Early research on venereal diseases.

EVENT: Edward Jenner successfully uses smallpox vaccine
SIGNIFICANCE: Jenner inoculates 8-year old James Phipps, the first trial in the development of a vaccine that will eventually eradicate smallpox.
The granddaughter of apothecary Christopher Marshall, Elizabeth takes over the family business and brings it out of financial hardship. She is believed to be the second female apothecary in the US.

EVENT: Friedrich Sertürner isolates the narcotic compound of opium
SIGNIFICANCE: He names the compound morphine, after Morpheus, the Greek god of dreams.

In the Territory of Orleans (which will soon become Louisiana), laws are passed that ban the sale of deteriorated drugs, restrict the sale of poions, and require pharmacists to prove their qualifications.

EVENT: The Massachusetts Pharmacopoeia is published, providing a state guide to drug standards
SIGNIFICANCE: First pharmacopoeia in America. Physicians James Jackson and John Collins Warren identify articles that cure diseases and their best methods of preparation. The Massachusetts Pharmacopoeia is intended to be a standard of uniformity for all “professional men” in the United States.

EVENT: New York Hospital employs a full-time pharmaceutical practitioner
SIGNIFICANCE: An early example of the pharmacist being separate from the physician. (Prior to this, most hospital pharmacists were apprentice physicians.)

Courtois serves as a pharmacist in the French army. He discovers iodine when he accidentally adds too much sulfuric acid to seaweed ash, which releases a vapor that condenses and then crystallizes. After investigating its properties, his work is publicly announced and the element named.

Following fraudulent production of fake smallpox vaccines, this law attempts to regulate and encourage vaccinations. It is repealed in 1822 after a smallpox outbreak in North Carolina is traced back to the federal agent in charge.
With his new invention, Laennec is able to investigate the sounds made by the heart and lungs.

The first of many cholera pandemics, this wave of infection originates in Russia, where 1 million people die. Spreading through feces-infected water and food, the bacterium is passed to British soldiers who bring it to India where millions more die. The extensive reach of the British Empire spreads the disease to Spain, Africa, Indonesia, China, Japan, Italy, Germany, and America, where it kills 150,000 more people.

EVENT: Pharmacopoeia of the United States of America published
SIGNIFICANCE: First nationwide pharmacopeia in the US. Introduces official standards for all US pharmacists.

EVENT: Joseph-Bienaimé Caventou and Pierre-Joseph Pelletier isolate quinine
SIGNIFICANCE: Their discovery forms the basis of malaria treatment and alkaloid chemistry. They later discover brucine, cinchonine, colchicine, strychnine, and veratrine.
The first college of pharmacy in the US. Charles Marshall is chosen as its president.
The second college of pharmacy in the US.
Balard determines the properties and compounds of bromine and proves its presence in sea plants and animals.

EVENT: Samuel Guthrie, Justus von Liebig, and Eugene Soubeiran each discover chloroform independently
SIGNIFICANCE: Three scientists in three countries independently, simultaneously discover chloroform.

EVENT: Library of the Office of the Surgeon General of the Army established
SIGNIFICANCE: This library eventually becomes the National Library of Medicine.

EVENT: Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain founded

SIGNIFICANCE: One of the earliest anesthetics, ether proves extremely useful in surgery.

EVENT: Drug Importation Act establishes standards of quality, purity, and fitness of imported drug compounds
SIGNIFICANCE: This law is a response to a surplus of poor-quality drugs imported from Europe. Following concerns about the use of adulterated medications, the Act establishes purity standards according to the United States Pharmacopeia.

EVENT: Congress passes legislation making the USP an official compendium.
SIGNIFICANCE: Though the Drug Importation Act proved ineffective, it established the United States Pharmacopeia as the standard of quality.

EVENT: Elizabeth Blackwell becomes the first woman to earn a medical degree in the US
SIGNIFICANCE: Blackwell graduates from Geneva College in New York, where she had faced extensive gender discrimination. During her education there, she had frequently been excluded from labs and forced to sit separately at lectures.

EVENT: WIlliam Procter, Jr.'s Practical Pharmacy: The Arrangements, Apparatus, and Manipulations of the Pharmaceutical Shop and Laboratory published
SIGNIFICANCE: First pharmaceutical textbook published in the US. Procter, Jr. is widely considered the father of American pharmacy.
In 1851, pharmacists had convened in New York City to discuss the need for a national pharmacy organization. The following year, APhA was born.

EVENT: Friedrich Gaedcke isolates cocaine from coca leaves
SIGNIFICANCE: Within five years of Gaedcke's discovery, the compound is used as anesthetic. (The first US regulation involving cocaine will not come about until the Harrison Act of 1915.)

EVENT: Darwin's The Origin of Species published
Florence Nightingale establishes first training school for nurses at St. Thomas's Hospital
SIGNIFICANCE: First professional nursing school in the world. Nightingale comes to be known the "Lady with the Lamp," as she regularly patrols the hospital sick wards at night.

EVENT: Mary Putnam becomes first woman to graduate from a US college of pharmacy
SIGNIFICANCE: A graduate of New York City college of pharmacy, Putnam uses her pharmacy education as a stepping stone to medical school.

EVENT: Joseph Lister introduces antiseptic treatment of wounds
SIGNIFICANCE: Pioneer in preventitive medicine and antisepsis.
First international meeting of pharmacists. Germany, Austria, France, and Sweden are represented. (The US is not involved until the second Congress, in 1867.)

EVENT: Thomas Clifford Allbutt introduces clinical thermometer
SIGNIFICANCE: This short mercury thermometer proves a desirable alternative to the previous, foot-long device that took 20 minutes to register a patient's temperature.

EVENT: International Medical Congress held in Paris
SIGNIFICANCE: First international meeting of physicians. UK, US, Belgium, France, Holland, Prussia, Portugal, Russia, and Bavaria are represented.

22-year old Chesebrough travels to Titusville, a small Pennsylvania town where petroleum has recently been discovered. Shortly after arriving, he becomes intrigued by a naturally-occurring by-product of the oil drilling process that seems to have remarkable skin-restoring properties.

EVENT: American Public Health Association holds first meeting

SIGNIFICANCE: In addition to its medicinal properties, Kolbe notes that salicyic acid can be used as a food preservative.

EVENT: Louis Pasteur discovers streptococcus, staphylococcus, and pneumococcus
SIGNIFICANCE: Pasteur's research lays the groundwork for germ theory and modern microbiology.

EVENT: Louis Grimaux obtains codeine from morphine
SIGNIFICANCE: Early relief for pain and cough.
Clara Barton establishes the American Red Cross and serves as its president until 1904, when she resigns at age 83.
Named Mycobacterium tuberculosis in 1886.
Klebs also gains recognition for his pioneering work which demonstrates that microorganisms are responsible for infectious diseases.

EVENT: Albert King determines that malaria is transmitted by mosquitoes
SIGNIFICANCE: In order to eradicate malaria from Washington, D.C., King proposes enclosing the entire city in a giant mosquito net.

EVENT: Carl Koller uses cocaine in eye surgery
SIGNIFICANCE: The birth of localized anesthesia. Koller, a young ophthalmologist, uses cocaine as a surface anesthetic in eye surgery.
Bear down!

EVENT: Joseph Remington's Practice of Pharmacy published
SIGNIFICANCE: Widely considered the definitive text for the science and practice of pharmacy.

EVENT: H. H. Rusby makes lengthy trip to South America to study botanical drugs
SIGNIFICANCE: Rusby's research proves immensely important to the fields of botany and pharmacognosy. He later becomes the co-founder of the New York Botanical Garden.
Pharmacist John Pemberton creates the drink and sells it as a treatment for upset stomach, headaches, and fatigue. The original formula contains cocaine, which is legal at the time.
Limousin uses traditional glass-blowing techniques to create the earliest ampuls. He also gains renown for his invention of the medicine dropper.

EVENT: Pharmacist Jacob Baur establishes the Liquid Carbonic Company
SIGNIFICANCE: Called the father of the soda fountain, Baur manufactures carbon dioxide tanks from whch fizzy sodas can be made. By the beginning of the 20th century, soda fountains become a common drugstore fixture.

EVENT: American Pharmaceutical Association publishes National Formulary
SIGNIFICANCE: Establishes standards for botanicals and other drug products. In 1975, the United States Pharmacopeia and the National Formulary combine to create the USP-NF.
The result of a search for a non-addictive alternative to cocaine, benzocaine becomes a popular localized anesthetic.

EVENT: APhA Section on Pharmaceutical Education votes to encourage all pharmacy schools to establish a 3-year course of study
SIGNIFICANCE: Early step taken to standardize pharmacy education.

EVENT: Lunsford Richardson creates first version of Vicks VapoRub
SIGNIFICANCE: Originally called Vicks Croup and Pneumonia Salve, the compound is one of the first western drugs to contain menthol. The name is changed to VapoRub in 1911.

EVENT: Wilhelm Röntgen discovers medical use of x-rays
Zada Mary Cooper graduates from the University of Iowa College of Pharmacy
SIGNIFICANCE: Cooper is one of the earliest women to graduate from a US pharmacy school. She becomes an instructor at her alma mater, a position she holds until her retirement in 1942. Along the way, she helps to establish the women's section of APhA. She is considered the mother of both Kappa Epsilon and Rho Chi, and she comes to be known as the "grand and glorious lady of pharmacy."

EVENT: National Association of Retail Druggists formed
SIGNIFICANCE: The Association is organized, in part, to combat price-cutting by wholesale druggists.

EVENT: Marie and Pierre Curie discover radium and polonium
SIGNIFICANCE: The Curies' discovery and eventual isolation of radium earn them a Nobel Prize in 1903.

Dreser's discovery comes while studying the effects of codeine on breathing. Shortly thereafter, heroin is sold commercially by companies like Bayer for a variety of ailments, from cough to labor pains.

Working as the head of Bayer's laboratory, Dreser discovers acetylsalicylic acid. The name "aspirin" is a combination of the "A" from "acetyl" and "Spirea," the genus of a shrub that acts a source of salicylic acid.

EVENT: American Conference on Pharmaceutical Faculties (later American Association of Colleges of Pharmacy) founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Intercollegiate organization formed to represent and promote pharmacy education in the US.
Charles R. Walgreen purchases the pharmacy where he works in Chicago, marking the beginning of what will become a major drugstore chain.
Major development in clinical medicine and cardiology.

EVENT: William Dunbar discovers the toxin and antitoxin of hay fever
SIGNIFICANCE: A significant breakthrough in the study of allergies.

Patent medicine salesman Louis Liggett creates a manufacturing cooperative in Boston called United Drug Stores. Following World War I, the cooperative adopts the name Rexall, and grows into an international drugstore chain.

EVENT: National Association of Boards of Pharmacy established
SIGNIFICANCE: Formal body comprised of each state's board of pharmacy. Established to ensure public health and safety with licensure standards, etc.

EVENT: The Great American Fraud published by Samuel Hopkins Adams
SIGNIFICANCE: Significant work of muckraking journalism, published as a series in Collier's Weekly. Adams lambasts the patent medicine industry, revealing major issues stemming from a lack of regulation. His work helps to inspire the Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906.

EVENT: Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906
SIGNIFICANCE: Also known as the Wiley Act, this landmark law puts some of the earliest consumer safety regulations in place. It is responsible for the establishment of the Food and Drug Administration.

EVENT: Frederick F. Russell vaccinates US Army against typhoid fever
SIGNIFICANCE: Early example of pharmaceutical innovation during wartime.

Prohibits manufacturers from making false claims about the therapeutic effects of drugs. This law proves difficult to enforce, since it requires clear evidence that a manufacturer had fraudulent intent in falsely advertising a drug.
Founded by female students at the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy, this fraternity expands in 1917 to become a national organization and welcomes its first international chapter in 1956.
Requires prescriptions for products exceeding the allowable limit of narcotics and mandates increased record-keeping for physicians and pharmacists who dispense narcotics.
This virus quickly goes global, infecting as much as a third of the world’s population. The number of deaths is estimated to be over 50 million worldwide, with about 675,000 in the United States.

EVENT: 18th Amendment (Prohibition) passed, alcohol becomes a prescription drug
SIGNIFICANCE: The U.S. government authorizes doctors to write prescriptions for medicinal alcohol. Patients are instructed to use it to treat a variety of ailments, including cancer, indigestion and depression.

Female representatives from the colleges of pharmacy at the Universities of Minnesota, Nebraska, and Iowa collaborate to establish this fraternity. Their goal is to promote women in pharmacy profession.

Though its full power is not realized until a decade later, Fleming's accidental discovery goes on to revolutionize the field of medicine. Penicillin is often considered one of the most significant discoveries of the 20th century.

EVENT: Pharmacists required to have a B.S. degree
SIGNIFICANCE: Before 1929, there were multiple avenues to becoming a pharmacist, including the 2-year Ph.G. (graduate in pharmacy) degree, the 3-year Ph.C. (pharmaceutical chemist) degree, and apprenticeship training. In 1929, the requirements are changed to require pharmacists to have a B.S. degree.

EVENT: Max Knoll and Ernst Ruska develop electron microscope
SIGNIFICANCE: Significant breakthrough for various fields of science. Provides a level of detail that previous microscopes could not produce.

EVENT: American Conference of Pharmaceutical Faculties (AACP) approves a 4-year baccalaureate degree for all member schools
SIGNIFICANCE: Signals a formal transition toward collegiate education.

EVENT: National Association of Chain Drug Stores founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Founded by Robert Bolger, this industry body is created to promote cooperation between drugstores, manufacturers, and consumers.

EVENT: Edward Kendall, Philip Hench, and Tadeus Reichstein isolate cortisone
SIGNIFICANCE: Collectively, Kendall, Hench, and Reichstein isolate close to 30 hormones. Cortisone proves to be a significant anti-inflammatory compound, useful in the treatment of arthritis.

EVENT: American Journal of Pharmaceutical Education established
SIGNIFICANCE: The journal's first editor, Dr. Rufus Lyman, later becomes the founding dean of this College of Pharmacy.

EVENT: Max Theiler develops yellow fever vaccine
SIGNIFICANCE: Theiler's discovery comes after studying yellow fever for more than a decade. Ironically, during his research, he contracts the disease from one of his own laboratory mice.

L.L. Skaggs opens a chain of self-service drugstores in the Midwest. First called Payless, its name is eventually changed to Self-Service Drug, Inc. In 1942, the company is dissolved and succeeded by “Owners Service Company," or OSCO.

Prior to 1937, sulfanilamide in tablet form had been shown to have significant curative power against streptococcal infections. When a salesman for S. E. Massengill Co. reports a demand for the drug in liquid form, the company's chemists begin experimenting and soon find that the drug dissolves in diethylene glycol, a chemical commonly used as antifreeze. Without testing the new compound for toxicity, the company sends out shipments as far west as California and as far east as Virginia. In total, 107 people die, and the creator commits suicide. This event is one of the key factors in the passage of the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act the following year.
A formal recommendation is made that any hospital with at least 100 beds should employ a registered pharmacist.

EVENT: Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of 1938
SIGNIFICANCE: Replaces the obsolete Pure Food and Drug Act of 1906, adding more robust consumer safety regulations. Implements greater governmental oversight of the drug industry, and requires drugs to be proved safe prior to marketing.

EVENT: Howard Florey and Ernst Chain develop penicillin for therapeutic use
SIGNIFICANCE: The US government keeps penicillin a closely-guarded secret, and it proves critical to the Allies' victory in World War II.

EVENT: American Institute of the History of Pharmacy (AIHP) founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Headquartered at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, AIHP holds extensive pharmacy archives and publishes the journal Pharmacy in History.

EVENT: The American Society of Hospital Pharmacists established (now American Society of Health-System Pharmacists)
SIGNIFICANCE: Prior to 1942, hospital pharmacy had not had distinct representation in the industry. Thus, the American Society of Hospital Pharmacists is formed, with a charter membership of 153 at the 1942 APhA Annual Meeting in Denver.

EVENT: Robert Woodward and William Doering synthesize quinine
SIGNIFICANCE: Major breakthrough in the treatment of malaria.
Following World War II, several new classes of drugs are introduced, including antihistamines, tranquilizers, antidepressants, proton-pump inhibitors, and anti-hypertensives.

On September 1, 1947, the University of Arizona College of Pharmacy opens thanks to a 23-year campaign led by Tucson pharmacist Andrew P. Martin and the Arizona Pharmacy Association. Under the instruction of three faculty members, the first 25 students complete the majority of their studies in a surplus Army hut.

EVENT: Great Moments in Pharmacy series begun
SIGNIFICANCE: Sponsored by Parke, Davis & Company, this series of paintings by artist Robert Thom and historian George Bender bring pharmacy history to life as never before. The Great Moments in Medicine series follows, with a combined 85 paintings.
WHO’s Constitution comes into force on April 7, 1948, a date we now celebrate as World Health Day.
This Amendment defines the kinds of drugs that can be used safely without medical supervision, and those that must be used under prescription by a licensed practitioner.

EVENT: Poison Control Center opens at UA College of Pharmacy
SIGNIFICANCE: In the early 1950s, Dr. Albert Picchioni, who had trained at the country's first Poison Control Center, moves to Tucson. In 1955, he founds the country's second Center, located here in the College of Pharmacy.

EVENT: The Upjohn Pharmacy opens in Disneyland
SIGNIFICANCE: One of the original lessees of Main Street U.S.A., the Upjohn Pharmacy showcases pharmacy "then and now."
In the two years before the vaccine was widely available, the average number of polio cases in the U.S. was more than 45,000. By 1962, that number drops to 910.
Originally marketed as "Tylenol Elixir for Children," the product's packing is modeled after a fire engine and advertised "for little hotheads."

EVENT: First pressurized metered dose inhaler approved
SIGNIFICANCE: Riker Pharmaceuticals (now 3M Pharmaceuticals) introduces the first pressurized metered dose inhaler, a significant development for drug delivery.

In February 1957, a new influenza A (H2N2) virus emerges in East Asia, triggering a pandemic. It is reported in Singapore in February 1957, Hong Kong in April 1957, and in coastal cities in the United States in summer 1957. The estimated number of deaths is 1.1 million worldwide and 116,000 in the United States.

Between 1957 and 1962, pregnant women all over the world take thalidomide, a non-barbiturate sedative, for morning sickness. After it is discovered that the drug causes birth defects and infant mortality, the Drug Efficacy Amendment is adopted, but not before some 10,000 children are affected. The incident will later be mentioned in Billy Joel's hit song "We Didn't Start the Fire."

EVENT: First drug information center established at the University of Kentucky
SIGNIFICANCE: Its creation marks a significant step in the transition of the pharmacist as drug distributor to the pharmacist as medication therapy expert.
The first Rite-Aid store opens as Thrif D Discount Center in Scranton, Pennsylvania. By 1965, the company has expanded to five states, but the "Rite-Aid" name will not be introduced until 1968.
Following the thalidomide disaster, this law requires manufacturers to report adverse drug reactions to the FDA and it mandates proof of efficacy for approval of new drugs.
The first CVS (Consumer Value Stores) store is founded in Lowell, Massachusetts, selling health and beauty products. Within a year, the chain grows to 17 locations.
On July 30, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signs into law the bill that leads to Medicare and Medicaid. This law formally introduces the concept of a consultant pharmacist.
Jesse Hurlbut, the former Inspector of the Arizona State Board of Pharmacy, donates his personal collection of pharmacy artifacts to this college to establish the History of Arizona Pharmacy Museum.

EVENT: Vice President Hubert Humphrey, RPh, runs for President against Richard Nixon
SIGNIFICANCE: Hubert Humprey, a career pharmacist, Minnesota Senator, and US Vice President runs against Nixon and loses the election by less than 1% of the popular vote

EVENT: American Society of Consultant Pharmacists established
SIGNIFICANCE: Founded to represent pharmacists, health care professionals, and students serving the medication needs of older adults.
Establishes Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and creates five controlled substance schedules with prescription limitations for each.

Requires dangerous substances to be packaged in child-resistant containers. Packaging must be significantly difficult for children under five years of age to open within a reasonable time, but not difficult for adults to use properly.

EVENT: First dry powder inhaler approved in the US
SIGNIFICANCE: A new form of aerosol drug delivery, the Intal Spinhaler becomes the first dry powder inhaler.

In June 1971, President Nixon calls drug abuse “public enemy number one,” and he increases federal funding to combat it. The so-called "War on Drugs" accelerates during Ronald Reagan's presidency, when the crack cocaine epidemic reaches its height. In 1984, Nancy Reagan spearheads the famous "Just Say No" campaign.

EVENT: American Society for Pharmaceutical Law founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Created as a nonprofit organization for attorneys and pharmacists with an interest in law as it applies to the pharmacy profession.

EVENT: APhA establishes Board of Pharmaceutical Specialities
SIGNIFICANCE: The APhA House of Delegates recommends a "board with independent decision-making authority be established." Its purpose is to recognize specialized knowledge, demand, education, and training. In 1978, the Board recognizes nuclear pharmacy as its first specialty.
Requires the FDA to establish standards of performance for medical devices.

EVENT: Genentech, one of the earliest biotechnology companies, founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Genentech helps to usher in the era of biotechnology-based medicine. Other companies soon follow, including Biogen (1978), Amgen (1980), and Immunex (1981).
This anti-ulcer medication begins the era of blockbuster drugs, earning over $1 billion per year.

EVENT: American College of Clinical Pharmacy founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Professional scientific society founded to provide leadership, education, advocacy for clinical pharmacists.

The CDC publishes a report about five previously healthy homosexual men becoming infected with Pneumocystis pneumonia. In 1982, The New York Times publishes an article about the new immune system disorder, which, by that time, has affected 335 people, killing 136 of them.
In Chicago, bottles of Tylenol are found to have been mysteriously laced with potassium cyanide. The incident leads to 7 deaths and results in tamper-resistant drug packaging.
Following the Tylenol murders, drug products are now required to bear tamper-evident packaging such as a foil induction seal, safety cap, triple-seal packaging, or an outer plastic safety seal.
In response to the Tylenol murders, this legislation makes tampering with consumer products a federal offense.
Following the start of the AIDS epidemic, this law provides tax and licensing incentives to manufacturers to develop drugs for diseased populations of 200,000 people or fewer.

EVENT: Drug Price Competition Act of 1984 (AKA Hatch-Waxman Act)
SIGNIFICANCE: This law marks the rise of the generic drug industry. It amends the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act and creates an abbreviated new drug application process that requires only bioequivalence studies.
This law protects drug companies from lawsuits and liabilities resulting from vaccine-related injuries.
This program provides federal compensation for victims of vaccine-related injuries.
AZT becomes the first drug approved as a treatment for AIDS.

The Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer (or simply "The Montreal Protocol") is passed. This international treaty seeks to phase out all CFC propellants from consumer and medical products

Following the success of Tagamet, drug companies race to find the next blockbuster drug. In 1987, Prozac becomes the first Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI) and it revolutionizes the field of mental health.

EVENT: This is Your Brain on Drugs campaign premieres
SIGNIFICANCE: One the most famous public service announcements in television history, this campaign featured dramatic scenes representing the harms of drug abuse.

EVENT: First multidose dry powder inhalers approved
SIGNIFICANCE: The Serevent Diskhaler and Pulmicort Turbuhaler are the first dry powder inhalers to allow for different dosages.

EVENT: Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy founded
SIGNIFICANCE: Organization created to represent managed care pharmacy, a healthcare delivery system that aims to improve quality and accessibility of health care in the most cost-effective manner.

Though it is difficult to pinpoint a specific start date, the first wave of the opioid epidemic begins around 1991, when opioid-involved deaths rise sharply following an increase in their prescription. By 1999, 86% of patients taking opioids use them for non-cancer pain.

EVENT: Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994
SIGNIFICANCE: Defines "dietary supplement" and lays out specific types of substantiated claims manufacturers can make.

EVENT: FDA approval of protease inhibitor drug
SIGNIFICANCE: Saquinavir became the first protease inhibitor to receive FDA approval, marking a new class of AIDS treatment.

EVENT: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA)
SIGNIFICANCE: Implements protections for patient information and specifies patients' rights regarding approval of access to records. Also requires "minimum necessary" use and disclosure of records.
Beginning one week after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, letters containing anthrax spores are sent to several media outlets and senators.

EVENT: 21st Century Nanotechnology Research and Development Act
SIGNIFICANCE: Beginning in 1999, President Clinton advocates for scientific and technological developments in nanoscale projects. In 2003, President Bush signs this landmark Act into law, unlocking billions of dollars for research.
Believed to have spread from animals to humans, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) affects over 8,000 people in 27 countries and causes 774 deaths.

Introduced in 1999, popular painkiller Vioxx is pulled from the market after it is shown to increase the risk of heart attack and stroke. This event marks a significant moment in the regulation of prescription drugs.
After predicting that an inhaled form of insulin would be a massive success as an alternative to injection, Pfizer soon pulls Exubera due to lackluster sales.

First detected in the United States, this virus spreads quickly across the world. It contains a unique combination of influenza genes not previously identified in animals or humans. Between April 2009 to April 2010, there are estimated to be over 60 million cases and 12,000 deaths in the United States due to the virus.

Part of the Affordable Care Act, the Sunshine Act requires manufacturers to disclose payments made to physicians or teaching hospitals, as well as physician ownership or investment interests held in those companies.

On March 23, 2014, the World Health Organization reports cases of Ebola Virus Disease in the rural region of southeastern Guinea. The identification of these early cases marks the beginning of the West Africa Ebola epidemic, the largest in history.

EVENT: Voluntary drug recall due to nitrosamines contamination
SIGNIFICANCE: A massive quantity of antihypertensive drugs are recalled due to contamination from a source in China.

EVENT: E-cigarettes become a topic of Congressional hearings

SIGNIFICANCE: Originating in Wuhan, China, the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus quickly spreads across the world, causing the deaths of millions. Lockdown orders and face mask mandates are implemented in many parts of the world, as hospitals and health systems face unprecedented strain.

Under the initiative known as "Operation Warp Speed," the US government pours billions of dollars into vaccine research in an attempt to accelerate the fight against COVID-19. Two vaccines emerge in late 2020, one from Pfizer and BioNTech and the other from Moderna. Both are granted an emergency use authorization by the FDA, and the first doses are administered in December 2020.
